div1.p: I write this note just to tell you that I am again indebted to you—who I have often been before. Your friends, Mr. and Mrs. Slade Kendrick have been called on me, and we talked about a number of matters that would have interested you (I wish you could have been here); and we talked about you. We share an interest in you and your epic.

I was sorry not to see you last August when I was briefly. in Columbia; but Lucile so much needs to talk with you, and gets to see you so little, that I thought it not fait to rob her--and you--of the time you need together. I think her book is going well, albeit slowly, and I am now convinced that it will be a really good biography. I suppose her main difficulty is that there is so much to tell about you that it is hard to make a selection. She ought to have ten volumes rather than one.

Is there any possibility that you will be giving another lecture at Cornell? I expect to be here until February and would of course love to see you. I would be glad to put you up at my apartment which may not have all the comforts of Skyrim but would certainly afford a warm welcome.

closer.salute: With best wishes, now and always,
